clinical_study.brief_title: Associated Joint Pain With Controlled Ankle Movement (CAM) Walker Boot Wear
clinical_study.official_title: Associated Joint Pain With CAM Walking Boot Wear

brief_summary.textblock: This is a prospective randomized, control trial investigating ankle pain resulting from the use of CAM Walking Boots.

detailed_description.textblock: The study compares ankle pain, physical function and quality of life for patients that wear the CAM Walking boots for 4 weeks and 12 weeks respectively.

primary_outcome.time_frame: when transitioning out of the boot at 4 or 12 weeks
primary_outcome.description: Self-reported outcome measure developed to assess physical function of patients with foot and ankle impairments. It is divided into two subscales: Activities of Daily Living (21 items) and Sports (8 items). Each item is score on a 5-point Likert scale from "No Difficulty" to "Unable to do." The overall score is reported as a percentage with 100% as no dysfunction.

primary_outcome.time_frame: when transitioning out of the boot at 4 or 12 weeks
primary_outcome.description: The SF-36 is a 36-item scale designed to report on health related quality of life. The score is reported as 9 sub-scales: Physical functioning, Role functioning/ physical, Role functioning/ emotional, Energy/fatigue, Emotional well-being, Social functioning, Pain, General health, Health change. Each sub scale is reported as a score from 0 (worst outcome) to 100 (best outcome).

primary_outcome.time_frame: when transitioning out of the boot at 4 or 12 weeks
primary_outcome.description: Visual Analogue Scales are used to measure values that range across a continuum of values, such as pain. It is a single item survey that is reported as a score from 0, "No pain," to 100 "The worst pain possible."

intervention.description: Each arm will be given a different amount of time to wear the CAM walking Boot for their injury.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- All patients enrolled in the study must have an injury that requires wear of a CAM walking boot for at least two weeks and have ambulation ad libitum without other aids (e.g crutches, canes, scooters, wheelchairs, etc.).
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patients will be excluded from the study if they are a recent post-operative patient for lower extremity injury, have an additional acute injury to a lower extremity or back other than the foot or ankle injury being treated by the CAM walking boot at the time of initiation of treatment, have an ongoing or history of lower extremity joint injury, arthritis, or back pain or have restricted weightbearing as instructed by a physician (i.e. for ankle fracture that cannot weightbear).
